awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Economics: Measuring the Elasticity of Nutrition Among Mothers of Young Children
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding how food purchasing behaviors by low-income households change in response to shocks in prices or income is crucial for the design of policy to counter food insecurity and malnutrition. For rural households with young children, these shocks are becoming increasingly important as incomes and prices change unpredictably due to pandemics, wars, and climates change. This research builds on an on-going field experiment to study how responsive food preferences are to changes in price and income among women with young children and how outside information on nutrition alters these preferences. The focus is on understanding whether providing nutritional information in addition to income support leads to better nutritional choices than providing income support alone.  The results of this research will improve the design of social protection programs, such as the bundle of services to provide, and the optimal size of support.  Besides helping researchers to model the economic impacts of adverse shocks, the results will also help improve the efficiency of social support programs, thus improving the wellbeing of low-income people as well reducing the fiscal burden of such programs.  The results could also help establish the US as the global leader in social support programs. 
  
Estimating unbiased price and income elasticities of nutrient consumption in low-income rural settings is difficult, even though these are critical to the efficient design social support programs.   This DDRIG exploits random variation in expenditure in an on-going RCT that randomly assigns households with younger children to receive cash transfers of various amounts.  The project design allows the PIs to also test whether providing nutritional information in addition to income support improves nutritional outcomes relative to only income support.  The PIs supplement this expenditure variation with a set of willingness-to-pay experiments during a lean-season household survey. With random variation in multiple dimensions, the PIs instrument for prices and income and estimate an Almost Ideal Demand System to obtain a complete picture of household preferences for foods and micronutrients.  The results of this research will improve the design of social protection programs, such as the bundle of services to provide, as well as the optimal size of support.  Besides illuminating the modelling of economic impacts of adverse shocks, the results of this research will also help improve the efficiency of social support programs, thus improving the wellbeing of low-income people as well reducing the fiscal burden of such programs.  The results could also help establish the US as the global leader in social support programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award enabled data collection for a lean season midline survey alongside the "Maziko" trial - a cluster randomized trial designed to test the effectiveness and complementarities of cash transfers alongside a comprehensive behavior change intervention designed to improve the nutritional status of children under five in rural Malawi. 

The trial randomly assigned 156 care center catchment areas into one of four experimental arms: 1) a standard of care arm, 2) a behavior change arm, 3) a "low cash" arm in which the behavior change intervention was combined with a $17/month cash transfer, and 4) a "high cash" arm in which the behavior change intervention was combined with a $43/month cash transfer. The survey enabled by this award collected data on 1,307 households where the woman who served as the primary participant in the Maziko trial was pregnant during the study's baseline survey. The data collection was intended to study the protective effects of the abovementioned intervention during Malawi's hunger season among households with very young children in crucial development periods. 

The primary aim of this award was to measure the elasticity of demand for micronutrient-dense foods with respect to income. Put more plainly, the aim was to measure how the composition of diets changes as income increases. Our results suggest that dietary quantity remains fairly stable regardless of changes in income. For every 1 percent change in income, spending on food increases by 0.8 to 0.9 percent, and caloric availability in household diets increases by 0.41 to 0.56 percent. In contrast, our analysis suggests that dietary quality is more responsive to changes in income. For every 1 percent change in income, households increase their spending on spending on tubers by 3.3 percent and animal-sourced foods by 1.5 percent. Accordingly, they increase the availability of Thiamin in their diets by 2.7 percent and the availability of Folate by 0.922 percent. 

These findings have two broader implications. First, even in an impoverished setting such as rural Malawi during the lean season, households seem to exhibit a relative preference for increasing their dietary diversity over their overall food consumption. This, in turn, may mean that policymakers may be able to drive change in dietary diversity and the availability of certain micronutrients with relatively small transfers or subsidies. However, changing overall food consumption and caloric availability may prove more resource-intensive. 

A secondary aim of this award was to study if "experimental" estimates of these elasticities that leverage the randomized assignment of the cash transfers as part of the Maziko trial substantially differ from more traditional estimates using observational data. We show that on "topline" outcomes - total food consumption and caloric availability - our estimates are very close in magnitude and not statistically different from traditional observational elasticity estimates. While there are several estimates where we detect differences, the majority of our estimates are qualitatively larger than observational estimates. These findings suggest that, at least in this context, observational elasticity estimates are not severely biased by omitted variable bias due to differences in preferences or simultaneity created by violations of the recursive principle of agricultural household models. 

Finally, this award enabled a household survey during Malawi's severe lean season to study the extent to which the Maziko interventions provided protective effects. Concordant with the conclusions above, we show that smaller transfers intended to cover the price of an "adequate" diet for a mother and her child increased dietary diversity but did not have a detectable effect on food insecurity. Conversely, a larger transfer, designed to cover the cost of an adequate diet for the entire household, increased food security while also decreasing measured food insecurity and increasing the caloric availability in household diets and availability of Thiamin, Folate, and Vitamin B. These results were accompanied by decreases in maternal depression among households who received transfers regardless of size. Across outcomes, we observe no evidence of a protective effect associated with the behavior change intervention alone.
